content.question:
For a middle school science project, Jalen measured the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of <math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math> vinegar products. The summary statistics for the values of the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> are shown in the following computer output.

<math alttext="Variable" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Variable</mtext></math>
<math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>N</mtext></math>
<math alttext="Mean" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Mean</mtext></math>
<math alttext="Median" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Median</mtext></math>
<math alttext="Standard Deviation" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>StDev</mtext></math>
<math alttext="Minimum" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Minimum</mtext></math>
<math alttext="Maximum" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Maximum</mtext></math>
<math alttext="Q 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q1</mtext></math>
<math alttext="Q 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q3</mtext></math>

<math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> 
<math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math>
<math alttext="2.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.50</mn></math>
<math alttext="2.49" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.49</mn></math>
<math alttext="0.26" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.26</mn></math>
<math alttext="2.11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.11</mn></math>
<math alttext="2.93" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.93</mn></math>
<math alttext="2.23" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.23</mn></math>
<math alttext="2.78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.78</mn></math>

Based on the <math alttext="1.5 times I Q R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.5</mn><mo>Ã—</mo><mtext>IQR</mtext></math> rule for outliers, which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: The minimum <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value of <math alttext="2.11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.11</mn></math> is an outlier, and no other <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value could be identified as an outlier.

The maximum <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value of <math alttext="2.93" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.93</mn></math> is an outlier, and no other <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value could be identified as an outlier.

The minimum <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value of <math alttext="2.11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.11</mn></math> is an outlier, and there could be other <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> values identified as outliers that are below the first quartile, but no <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value above the third quartile could be identified as an outlier.

The maximum <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value of <math alttext="2.93" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.93</mn></math> is an outlier, and there could be other <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> values identified as outliers that are above the third quartile, but no <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> value below the first quartile could be identified as an outlier.
There are no <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> values that could be identified as outliers.

content.answer: There are no <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> values that could be identified as outliers.

topic.text: 1.7: Summary Statistics for a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
